Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 10:58AM mrs-mjt wrote: My radiologist called this morning, and as I expected, she recommends surgery to remove the radial scar for two reasons.   1. Even though she got a good biopsy (25 cores), cancer can still be lurking when there is a radial scar and she prefers to make sure nothing is there.    2. My mammogram initially revealed an architectural distortion which was confirmed at biopsy to be a radial scar.  In that case, removal is recommended.  If there had not been architectural distortion on the mammo and they found a radial scar incidentally at biopsy, then you might watch it for changes instead of removing it.  So apparently, the architectural distortion is the reason she's recommending removal.  I have a consult with surgeon in the morning.
Posts.Title: Radial Scar ?'s cemjo3 marie5890

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 10:25AM mrs-mjt wrote: I also was just diagnosed with radial scar formation so am joining your club.  Waiting to talk to the radiologist who did my biopsy to see what she recommends (someone else gave me the results of pathology).   I've been researching online trying to learn more.  After your biopsy, was it recommended that your radial scar be removed surgically?  If so, what reason did they give you for doing so?  I'll let you know what I find out when I talk to my radiologist.

Posts.Content: mrs-mjt wrote: I go to the imaging facility for wire localization at 10:30, then check in at a surgical facility (different location) at 2:00 for a 3:15 p.m. excisional biopsy.    That's 4 3/4 hours between procedures.  Does that seem a bit bizarre or is it normal?  How long does a wire localization take?   I was told to be VERY careful not to move around after wire was inserted so it'll stay in place.   Should I be concerned about the 4 3/4 hour wait between procedures?  Or should I just cool it, take a book to read while I sit & wait at the hospital? Thanks! Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 09:14AM mrs-mjt wrote: Thanks for sharing.  Sounds like others also had long waits so I'll just be prepared to wait and read my book.   Bigapple, They want the wire localization at the same facility I had my MRI biopsy, etc.. done and I also trust the radiologist doing the procedure at that facility since we've developed a good rapport.  The hospital is nearby so it's not problematic for me to change locations although you mentioning an ambulance transport made me wonder.  Can't I just have my husband drive me to the surgery center after the wire localization?  Sure don't want to go by ambulance.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 05:16PM - edited Apr 15, 2009 05:18PM by mrs-mjt I don't know what is normal for others, but I'll share my experience in case it helps.  I had my annual mammo on Feb 3 and was called back for diagnostic mammo and ultrasound on Feb 9 which was BIRADS 4.  Then had a breast MRI on Feb 27 and a MRI guided core biopsy on March 10.  I'm scheduled for an excisional biopsy on April 22 so I've been at this 11 weeks.
Posts.Title: Finally got biopsy appointment.... Ostia Ostia

Posts.Content: mrs-mjt wrote: The radiologist called this a.m. and is recommending an MRI-guided breast biopsy scheduled for Thur., March 5.   BIRADS 4.   I've already had a diagnostic mammo, ultrasound and an MRI which revealed an enhancement in L breast.   The tech botched my MRI on Feb 27 so had to have it repeated on Feb 28.  Long story, but suffice it to say that it was unpleasant experience and the dept manager called it a disaster.  I'd like to be better prepared for the MRI guided breast biopsy so please give me the pros and cons of the procedure so I know what to expect as well as questions I should ask beforehand.  Thanks! Posts.Title: My first post: Please tell me about MRI-guided biopsy mrs-mjt mrs-mjt

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 05:28AM - edited Mar 16, 2009 03:11PM by mrs-mjt I wanted to share about my MRI guided biopsy on March 10 in case others are looking for info on this procedure as I was.  It was done via a vacuum-assisted device.   My situation may be unique because I received sedation (versed) and a pain killer (fentanyl) through my IV plus the lidocaine they shoot into the breast so I didn't feel a thing!  I was in la-la during the 2 hour procedure and glad to be there!  I did hear radiologist talking to me when they nicked my skin and when she inserted the needle, etc. but must've "slept" some as the procedure just flew by.  After tissue was removed, they put in a metal marker and then I had a mammogram to confirm its placement.  After the biopsy, my chest was wrapped in a pressure guaze bandage (like a big ace bandage) and I kept a ice pack on my chest the ENTIRE DAY.  I bruise very easily and still can't believe that I have absolutely no bruising or swelling so icing is VERY important.  My brother does MRI's in another state and they do not give their patients sedation whereas the facility I had mine done at said they always give sedation because it is a long procedure (2 hours).    I'm not one who likes to take medicationg but I'm glad I did in this case although perhaps it would've been fine without it, too.   Anyway, I read of another poster's very negative experience with MRI guided biopsy on this board and thought I'd share another perspective to encourage those who need to have this procedure done.    I have radial scar formation which is B9 so waiting to hear if I need it removed or can just keep an eye on it.
Posts.Title: My first post: Please tell me about MRI-guided biopsy mrs-mjt mrs-mjt

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 11:07PM - edited Mar 2, 2009 11:37PM by mrs-mjt Deanna,  Thanks for the reply. As for your question re: what the lesion looks like, I don't have the rad report in my hands yet but will get it.  My gyn called today and said it was 1.3 cm irregular enhancing lesion.  The mammo revealed an architectural distortion.  When I met with the rad, she said I have "breasts from h*ll" as they are extremely dense which is why she ordered an MRI to help with her diagnosis.  The rad hopes it is radial scarring which is a benign condition.  In my research, I found that radial scarring mimics invasive cancer so I assumed I would need a biopsy after the MRI to make that determination.   I saw the spiculations on the mammo, but apparently there is NOT a definable mass.    I appreciate any info/links on MRI guided biopsy.
